article.title: Amara_Sinha
article.paragraph: Amara Sinha(orSimha) (c. AD 375) was aSanskritgrammarianandpoet, of whose personal history hardly anything is known.citation neededOctober 2014

He is said to have been "one of the nine gems that adorned the throne ofVikramaditya," and according to the evidence ofXuanzang, this is theChandragupta Vikramaditya(Chandragupta II) that flourished about AD 375.sfnChisholm1911Other sources describe him as flourishing in c. AD 700."Amara-Simha" inChambers's Encyclopdia. London:George Newnes, 1961, Vol. 1, p. 311.

Most of his work was destroyed, with the exception of what is the celebratedAmara-Kosha(Treasury of Amara), a vocabulary of Sanskrit roots, in three books, and hence sometimes calledTrikandaor the "Tripartite".sfnChisholm1911It is also known as "Namalinganushasana".

It contains 10,000 words, and is arranged, like other works of its class, in metre, to aid the memory. The first chapter of theKoshawas printed atRomein Tamil character in 1798. An edition of the entire work, with English notes and an index byHenry Thomas ColebrookeHT Colebrooke, appeared atSeramporein 1808. The Sanskrit text was printed atCalcuttain 1831. A French translation by ALA Loiseleur-Deslongchamps as published at Paris in 1839.sfnChisholm1911Benjamin L. RiceLouie Ricecompiled theKannadaversion of it and its available 4th edition was printed in 1927 which contains three khandas and 25 sargas.Amarakosha by Louie Rice edited by N.Balasubhramanyam
